It starts as a fairly conventional Slav Defence. 4. Nc3 is more common that 4. Bf4, but Bf4 can hardly be bad.
This can hardly be wrong, but 4....Bf5 is more active. As played the Bc8 becomes a very bad bishop, hemmed in by its own pawns.
This seems good, allowing the Bf1 to recapture on c4 if necessary.
Solid development again.
The knight finally goes to its natural square.
And the black queen comes out to menace b2.

Post Match Computer Analysis(PMCA) gives this as a mistake, and says the position is now level. It prefers 7. Qc2 with an advantage of 0.57 to white. I am not sure. Although white now ends up with doubled b pawns he has compensation with pressure down the a file. Incidentally I have found this position on the opening databases, and both the games continued with  7. b3?? Bb4 and black soon won a knight and later the game.
So the queens come off, but the only pieces to have been exchanged.
So the queens come off, but the only pieces to have been exchanged.
This pins comes in again, white has to be careful.
Wisely stopping the knight from coming in to e4.
Not sure that this helps black that much. c5 looks a rather thematic move to me, or trying to get in e6-e5.
White wisely connects rooks.
And black puts his king to a safer place.
Hitting the bishop.
Not given as a mistake by PMCA, but I prefer c5 or even a5, keeping the bishop active. Black is now a bit passive.
and white has pressure on a7.
And this is virtually the only way to save the a pawn.
Further cramping down on black's queen side.
Presumably with the long-term plan of eventually freeing his position a little with e6-e5
